Award.AwardTitle: Studies in Nuclear Physics and Fundamental Interactions at Indiana University
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is now a well established fact that the proton and neutron are made from constituents known as quarks and gluons. The research supported by this award investigates how a property of the proton called spin is distributed among its parts. The goal is to extract the gluon contribution to the spin of the proton and compare this with theoretical predictions. The group will also search for indications that strongly interacting matter is expected based on symmetry principles. For example, interactions of neutrinos with nuclei is important for the understanding of supernova explosions. In addition, this group will measure the lifetime of the free neutron, since this is important input to test the Big Bang theory of element creation.

More specifically, the research supported by this award investigates: (1) How the spin of the proton is distributed among its parts. Particles emitted when high-energy beams of spin-aligned protons collide in the STAR detector at Brookhaven National Laboratory's Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider can reveal how much of the proton's spin is carried by its gluons or by different types of quarks and anti-quarks. The group will search for the gluon contribution to the spin of the proton and explore spin differences among antiquarks. They will also measure how polarized quarks turn into mesons and baryons and search for indications that strongly interacting matter breaks mirror symmetry;(2) The properties and interactions of neutrinos in nuclei with a large number of neutrons and protons: this is important for the understanding of supernova explosions; (3) How long the free neutron lives: this is important input to test the Big Bang theory of element creation; and (4) whether or not neutrons possess exotic interactions that are not (yet) a part of our current list of forces.

The research activities of the group will contribute toward educating the next generation of skilled PhD scientists for jobs in research and teaching universities, industry and national labs, and medical and computer technology. The investigators co-organize and lecture at summer schools. They participate in the NSF REU program. They mentor their postdocs to facilitate their future entry into teaching and research institutions and the scientific community. They develop undergraduate laboratories emphasizing nuclear technology, bring undergraduates on field trips and assist with programs that encourage pre-college participation in the Indiana University science curriculum. They engage bright young undergraduates in science through jobs or projects, which develop the research skills they will need for success in graduate school. They reach out to the local community through a variety of activities to awaken the interest of students in the local public school system by visiting local high school science classes, acting as judges in local science fairs and for the State Science Olympiad, and presenting physics demonstrations at the Indiana State Fair. They actively recruit female and minority applicants for positions at all levels within the group and the physics department by serving on selection committees for faculty searches and research fellowships for women. They work to make their activities known to the public at large through laboratory tours and Open House presentations, science cafe discussions, radio interviews, and press releases in the local media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the period of this grant the nuclear physics group at Indiana University concentrated our scientific efforts on experiments that directly address four key areas of inquiry:
•    How do the quarks and gluons that make up the proton contribute to its observable properties?
•    Do neutrinos interact with large nuclei as expected?
•    Can we find evidence for a process which would not retrace itself if time ran backwards?
•    How can we use the strong nuclear force to unravel the details of much weaker forces?

Protons are made of electrically charged objects called 'quarks,' which are bound tightly together by swarms of massless, electrically neutral 'gluons.' These particles in the proton all spin and rotate around each other. The surprising discovery that only 1/3 of the total angular momentum of the proton is accounted for by the spinning quarks prompted IU researchers to study collisions of high-energy polarized protons at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory.  Using the STAR detector at RHIC, the direction and energy of the outgoing quarks can be precisely measured with the help of the Endcap Electromagnetic Calorimeter, a 30-ton device built at IU and funded by the US NSF. We have shown that the gluons inside the proton appear to contribute about another 1/3 of the proton angular momentum. We have also learned new information about how much of this angular momentum comes from different types of quarks, including the small but nonzero antimatter quarks which are known to pop in and out of existence inside the proton. IU researchers have also made progress in understanding the dynamics of the components of the spin of the proton which are normal to the direction of the proton’s momentum.

Most neutrino detector systems weigh many tons. By exploiting the constructive interference of neutrino waves, however, we have recently succeeded to see neutrinos in much lighter detectors of only several kilograms. As part of the COHERENT collaboration, IU developed a new type of detector to measure background processes at the Spallation Neutron Source at Oak Ridge National Lab and showed they would not obscure a search for these elusive neutrino signals. The COHERENT collaboration then succeeded to observe this so-called “coherent” neutrino interaction, with a size consistent with the theory of neutrino interactions with matter. IU developed a new type of neutrino detector using liquid argon and confirmed that the size of the coherent neutrino signal depends on the size of the nucleus in the expected way.

It is easy to tell when a home movie is being run backwards, but a film of two particles bouncing off each other gives no obvious visual clue.  Nature seems to prefer one direction of the ‘flow’ of time over the other for unknown reasons, and it is thought that similar processes could explain why the universe is mainly made of matter and not antimatter. The Indiana nuclear physics group  conducted R&D towards a new more sensitive search for an electric dipole moment (EDM) of the neutron, which can be nonzero only if time reversal symmetry is violated.

Members of the IU group used neutrons to look for the effects of the “weak” force of nature.  IU helped the NPDGamma collaboration to fuse spin-aligned neutrons with protons to detect a 30 part-per-billion lopsidedness in the emitted gamma-rays to make the first observation of the weak force between neutrons and protons. IU helped the UCNtau collaboration construct a device to collect neutrons in a uniquely shaped magnetic bowl to measure the neutron decay rate, which is very important to help test the Big Bang theory and the theory of weak interactions. IU helped the aCORN collaboration detect the lopsidedness in the electron-proton coincidence rate in neutron decay and provided new constraints on fundamental features of the weak interaction.

The Indiana nuclear physics group has a long tradition of training outstanding undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-docs who succeed as scientific researchers, educators, and in professional roles in the private sector. The IU students received their Ph.D.’s while being supported by this grant are now either in industry, universities, or national labs and are making essential use of their scientific and technical training. Several undergraduate students got their first real scientific research experiences in our group. We conduct several forms of scientific outreach to our local community through our annual Physics Department Open House, tours of our research facility, participation in exhibits at the local Wonderlab science museum, exhibits at the Indiana State Fair, and scientific demonstrations at local grade schools.
